data:
WEBVTT

00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.320
Hello, this is the Global News Podcast from the BBC World Service,

00:00:04.320 --> 00:00:09.120
with reports and analysis from across the world. The latest news, seven days a week.

00:00:09.120 --> 00:00:12.800
BBC World Service podcasts are supported by advertising.

00:00:15.920 --> 00:00:20.000
It's late night in London and we're recording an emergency episode of AmeriCast,

00:00:20.000 --> 00:00:24.480
with the news that Donald Trump has pleaded not guilty to 34 charges.

00:00:24.480 --> 00:00:29.120
We're going to be talking about what this means for Trump, for the Democrats and Republicans,

00:00:29.120 --> 00:00:32.720
and how it shifts the state of play for the 2024 election.

00:00:32.720 --> 00:00:35.200
You can hear all of the analysis on AmeriCast,

00:00:35.200 --> 00:00:38.080
just search for it wherever you get your BBC podcasts.

00:00:41.440 --> 00:00:47.040
This is a special edition of the Global News Podcast from the BBC World Service.

00:00:50.000 --> 00:00:55.600
I'm Charlotte Gallagher and at three hours GMT on Wednesday the 5th of April,

00:00:55.600 --> 00:01:01.840
this is an update on the criminal charges brought against the former US President Donald Trump.

00:01:01.840 --> 00:01:08.240
Shortly before we recorded this podcast, Mr Trump addressed his supporters at his Mar-a-Lago retreat

00:01:08.240 --> 00:01:14.640
in Florida, describing the case as election interference and saying his only crime had

00:01:14.640 --> 00:01:20.800
been to defend America from those who would destroy it. Earlier at a hearing in New York,

00:01:20.800 --> 00:01:27.520
he pleaded not guilty to all 34 charges brought against him, accusing him of falsifying business

00:01:27.520 --> 00:01:33.280
records to hide damaging information during the 2016 presidential election.

00:01:33.280 --> 00:01:38.560
We'll report from New York, Florida and the traditional Republican stronghold of Arizona.

00:01:44.000 --> 00:01:48.720
Even by the standards of his four at times tumultuous years in office,

00:01:48.720 --> 00:01:53.520
it's been an extraordinary day for Donald Trump and America.

00:01:53.520 --> 00:02:00.320
He made history by becoming the first serving or former US President to appear in court charged

00:02:00.320 --> 00:02:06.640
with criminal offences. At the hearing in New York, he pleaded not guilty to the 34 charges

00:02:06.640 --> 00:02:13.280
filed against him. They relate to three hush money payments ahead of the 2016 election,

00:02:13.280 --> 00:02:19.600
including one to the porn star Stormy Daniels. Mr Trump later flew back to Florida and addressed

00:02:19.600 --> 00:02:22.320
supporters at his Mar-a-Lago mansion.

00:02:22.320 --> 00:02:28.000
The only crime that I have committed is to fearlessly defend our nation from those who

00:02:28.000 --> 00:02:29.360
seek to destroy it.

00:02:34.080 --> 00:02:39.040
From the beginning, the Democrats spied on my campaign, remember that?

00:02:39.040 --> 00:02:46.800
They attacked me with an onslaught of fraudulent investigations. Russia, Russia, Russia, Ukraine,

00:02:46.800 --> 00:02:54.080
Ukraine, Ukraine. Impeachment hoax number one. Impeachment hoax number two. The illegal and

00:02:54.080 --> 00:02:58.720
unconstitutional raid on Mar-a-Lago right here.

00:03:00.720 --> 00:03:05.840
Our correspondent Barbara Pletosha was at Mar-a-Lago to hear Mr Trump's speech.

00:03:05.840 --> 00:03:11.440
He was back to his regular platform with his regular crowd and I think he seemed heartened

00:03:11.440 --> 00:03:17.040
by their cheers and their claps. But he also actually seemed pretty intense and angry still

00:03:17.040 --> 00:03:22.160
throughout the speech. And he did talk about, of course, the New York investigation, saying

00:03:22.160 --> 00:03:27.760
several times that it was aimed at interfering in the 2024 election and lashing out at the

00:03:27.760 --> 00:03:32.720
district attorney who brought it. But he didn't actually talk about it very much. He did talk

00:03:32.720 --> 00:03:37.360
about other cases. He talked at some length about the case involving the classified documents

00:03:37.360 --> 00:03:43.280
that he brought from the White House here to Mar-a-Lago and got some good boos from

00:03:43.280 --> 00:03:47.280
the crowd about that. And he talked about the Georgia case, which is this investigation

00:03:47.280 --> 00:03:51.680
into whether he tried to overturn the election in that state. So it could be that he's more

00:03:51.680 --> 00:03:56.000
concerned about the implication of those cases than this one.

00:03:56.000 --> 00:04:01.360
Earlier in the day, prosecutors in Manhattan said they'd identified a man who was a member

00:04:01.360 --> 00:04:06.800
of the Republican Party. The judge in Manhattan said they'd identified serious criminal conduct

00:04:06.800 --> 00:04:11.760
by the former president and would lay out their case at trial. Analysts suggest that

00:04:11.760 --> 00:04:16.400
could begin early next year. From New York, Gary O'Donohue reports.

00:04:16.400 --> 00:04:21.360
Trump 24! Trump 24! Trump 24!

00:04:21.360 --> 00:04:27.920
This was a day like no other in American history. A former president up before a judge on criminal

00:04:27.920 --> 00:04:33.520
charges. In the crowds of protesters, both pro and anti-Trump, and the world's media,

00:04:33.520 --> 00:04:38.960
Mr Trump's motorcade snaked its way from Trump Tower to the courtroom where he spent

00:04:38.960 --> 00:04:45.520
around two hours. Having railed against the proceedings in public, Mr Trump wore a sober,

00:04:45.520 --> 00:04:51.840
serious expression in the courtroom itself, speaking quietly to enter not guilty pleas

00:04:51.840 --> 00:04:58.960
and 34 charges brought against him. The charges relate to falsifying business records in combination

00:04:58.960 --> 00:05:04.880
with an attempt to contravene New York state election law. What that means in real terms

00:05:04.880 --> 00:05:11.120
is that he's accused of passing off payments to his lawyers as legal expenses when in fact

00:05:11.120 --> 00:05:17.440
they were to reimburse him for hush money payments. They included $130,000 to Stormy

00:05:17.440 --> 00:05:24.400
Daniels to keep quiet about an alleged sexual encounter. Alvin Bragg is the Manhattan district

00:05:24.400 --> 00:05:31.200
attorney. It is a felony to falsify business records with intent to defraud and intent

00:05:31.200 --> 00:05:39.040
to conceal another crime. That is exactly what this case is about. 34 false statements

00:05:39.040 --> 00:05:48.160
made to cover up other crimes. No matter who you are, we cannot and will not normalise

00:05:48.160 --> 00:05:53.840
serious criminal conduct. Prosecutors are also accusing the former president of a broad

00:05:53.840 --> 00:06:00.000
so-called catch and kill scheme, whereby potentially damaging stories were bought up by friendly

00:06:00.000 --> 00:06:05.920
publications and then sat on. Apart from the money to Stormy Daniels, they also referenced

00:06:05.920 --> 00:06:11.680
money paid to a former Playboy model and to a Trump Tower doorman who threatened to publish

00:06:11.680 --> 00:06:17.760
information about an alleged love child fathered by Mr Trump. One of Mr Trump's lawyers, Joe

00:06:17.760 --> 00:06:22.960
Tacopina, said the case should never have been brought. Today's unsealing of this indictment

00:06:22.960 --> 00:06:28.320
shows that the rule of law died in this country because while everyone is not above the law,

00:06:28.320 --> 00:06:32.720
no one's below it either. And if this man's name was not Donald J. Trump, there is no

00:06:32.720 --> 00:06:39.040
scenario we'd all be here today. Please understand that based on these charges. These are felony

00:06:39.040 --> 00:06:45.200
charges Mr Trump is facing, the more serious level of criminal conduct in the US legal

00:06:45.200 --> 00:06:52.000
system. In theory, they could carry jail terms of up to four years. But the Trump team have

00:06:52.000 --> 00:06:58.080
vowed to fight the charges every step of the way, and the next few months could see a whole

00:06:58.080 --> 00:07:03.840
series of motions challenging everything from the very basis of the case itself to where a

00:07:03.840 --> 00:07:10.960
possible trial should be held. Gary O'Donohue. The southwestern US state of Arizona has traditionally

00:07:10.960 --> 00:07:17.280
been seen as a Republican stronghold. But strong performances by the Democrats in recent years have

00:07:17.280 --> 00:07:22.480
challenged that view. Our correspondent Sophie Long has been to its biggest city, Phoenix,

00:07:22.480 --> 00:07:27.680
to get reaction from Republican supporters. In presidential elections, Arizona is one of the

00:07:27.680 --> 00:07:34.480
most contested and coveted states. It was once reliably Republican, but in 2020, it elected a

00:07:34.480 --> 00:07:39.920
Democratic president for the first time in nearly quarter of a century. And last year, voters here

00:07:39.920 --> 00:07:45.200
chose a Democratic governor. The Republican candidate who won Donald Trump's endorsement

00:07:45.200 --> 00:07:50.800
did not win the election. I've been a precinct committeeman in this precinct right here for 50

00:07:50.800 --> 00:07:56.720
years. Alberto Gutierrez is a lifelong ultra conservative Republican. He voted for Donald

00:07:56.720 --> 00:08:03.600
Trump in 2016 and a bit more reluctantly in 2020. But even he's had enough. We need to change. We

00:08:03.600 --> 00:08:12.000
need to find someone else, OK, down the road, others who are not as brash as Donald Trump,

00:08:12.000 --> 00:08:19.040
that can carry and rebuild the Republican Party. I think he did a great job for this country.

00:08:19.040 --> 00:08:24.080
Alberto's wife, Miriam, disagrees. She thinks the indictment is politically motivated,

00:08:24.080 --> 00:08:28.640
and she wants to see Donald Trump back in the White House to support American businesses and

00:08:28.640 --> 00:08:34.240
strong border control. She and Alberto emigrated the right way, they say, from Cuba to the United

00:08:34.240 --> 00:08:42.160
States. Believe me, if Trump runs, either he votes for Trump or I will divorce him. How do you like?

00:08:42.160 --> 00:08:48.720
After 62 years? Yeah, after 62 years, I will say goodbye.

00:08:48.720 --> 00:08:52.640
The many here, including at least two of Alberto and Miriam's five children,

00:08:52.640 --> 00:08:57.680
think it's time to say goodbye to Donald Trump and bring in fresh candidates to unify the

00:08:57.680 --> 00:09:02.800
Republican Party in Arizona and across the nation, regardless of whether Donald Trump

00:09:02.800 --> 00:09:09.200
is found guilty or not. Sophie Long. After Mr Trump addressed his supporters in Florida,

00:09:09.200 --> 00:09:14.400
I spoke to our correspondent, Michelle Fleury. I began by asking her what impact today's

00:09:14.400 --> 00:09:19.280
developments might have on his chances of winning another presidential election.

00:09:19.280 --> 00:09:27.360
It felt more like a campaign rally, quite frankly, than it did, you know, reflections on the day we

00:09:27.360 --> 00:09:33.680
just saw outside the courthouse in lower Manhattan. And this is someone who knows how to take advantage

00:09:33.680 --> 00:09:39.120
of situations. And I think that's what he's done from the moment we first saw the indictment.

00:09:39.120 --> 00:09:45.120
He immediately kind of used it as a rallying cry to his base, to his supporters, to kind of

00:09:45.120 --> 00:09:50.240
circle the wagons around him. He's used it to raise money, raising as much as $10 million

00:09:50.880 --> 00:09:55.760
since the indictment dropped. So I think we know sort of what it does for him politically,

00:09:55.760 --> 00:10:02.000
right from the beginning, people have been saying you can't kind of separate this legal case from

00:10:02.000 --> 00:10:05.680
the political implications. And I think we're seeing that in real time right now.

00:10:06.240 --> 00:10:10.640
You mentioned the money there that he's been raising, donations have been flooding in. It's

00:10:10.640 --> 00:10:15.760
going to be really hard, I think, isn't it, for another candidate to match that kind of money?

00:10:15.760 --> 00:10:21.120
And it's been fascinating to watch the response from Republicans. Mitt Romney, one of those who

00:10:21.120 --> 00:10:25.840
hasn't always been a fan, quite frankly, of Donald Trump, was out today saying that, you know,

00:10:25.840 --> 00:10:31.360
he was against this prosecution that has been brought by the district attorney here in New York,

00:10:31.360 --> 00:10:36.160
saying he didn't think it was sort of appropriate. And I think you're seeing that from the rank and

00:10:36.160 --> 00:10:41.280
file of the Republican Party. Right now, no one is speaking out against Donald Trump. In fact,

00:10:41.280 --> 00:10:46.320
they're all backing him. And that is going to make it very challenging for any Republican

00:10:46.320 --> 00:10:52.000
presidential hopefuls for 2024. How do you go up against Donald Trump in that context?

00:10:52.000 --> 00:10:56.720
What is something to keep an eye on is obviously the next court appearance, that's late December.

00:10:56.720 --> 00:11:00.800
And that comes just a couple of weeks before we start to see those first votes in the Republican

00:11:00.800 --> 00:11:06.080
primaries. And it seems maybe decades ago that this kind of thing would finish someone's

00:11:06.080 --> 00:11:11.440
political career, even if they were found not guilty. But so many people are flocking to him

00:11:11.440 --> 00:11:16.320
now, it could almost have the opposite effect. But I mean, this was never a traditional

00:11:16.320 --> 00:11:22.320
candidate from the very beginning. As you say, before Donald Trump, if anyone had had to go

00:11:22.320 --> 00:11:26.640
through something like the Access Hollywood tape that was revealed, that would have ended their

00:11:26.640 --> 00:11:30.960
political career. That hasn't been the case for this president. He's faced two impeachments,

00:11:30.960 --> 00:11:34.240
and now he faces a criminal case. And yet he's rising in the polls.

00:11:34.240 --> 00:11:36.320
That was Michelle Flurry.

00:11:39.120 --> 00:11:43.680
And that's all from us for now. But there will be another regular edition of the Global News

00:11:43.680 --> 00:11:49.680
Podcast later. Remember, you can comment on this podcast by sending us an email. The address is

00:11:49.680 --> 00:11:57.520
globalpodcast at bbc.co.uk. You can also find us on Twitter at Global News Pod. This edition was

00:11:57.520 --> 00:12:02.880
mixed by Caroline Driscoll and the producer was Harry Bly. The editor is Karen Martin.

00:12:02.880 --> 00:12:05.760
And I'm Charlotte Gallagher. Until next time, goodbye.

00:12:14.000 --> 00:12:18.640
It's late night in London, and we're recording an emergency episode of AmeriCast with the news

00:12:18.640 --> 00:12:24.080
that Donald Trump has pleaded not guilty to 34 charges. We're going to be talking about what

00:12:24.080 --> 00:12:28.720
this means for Trump, for the Democrats and Republicans, and how it shifts the state of play

00:12:28.720 --> 00:12:34.480
for the 2024 election. You can hear all of the analysis on AmeriCast. Just search for it wherever

00:12:34.480 --> 00:13:01.360
you get your BBC podcasts.
